text:
Thanks Brad for sharing the bottle! Poured into a taster showing translucent caramel brown with white foam lacing. 

The nose shows a lot of sweet Belgian yeast. 

The palate is medium bodied and lightly carbonated. Lightly tart with strong flavors of Belgian yeast.

Bottle, vintage 2008. Pours a clear dark brown beer with a quickly disappearing off white head on top. Aroma is rich, full with woody characters, red fruits, oak, some tart fruits and has vineous notes as well. Flavor is incredibly full, yet really sublte with light tarty notes, richness of red fruits, all sorts of berries and such. Has a body that is light tart and vineous, overall is quite fruity and almost sweetish. Mouthfeel is oily and silky, has a dry tart aftertaste that really lasts a long time. No carbonation going on, but what a great beer.

Bottle from the dregs run delivery. Thanks Craig! Pours hazy brown with a thin beige head. Aromas of wood, wine, sour funk, chocolate. Taste is light sour, light chocolate, red wine. Light sour finish.
Vinagre, madera y fruta para parar un tren. Similar a las rojas de Flandes.

2008 editie. Ziet er niet echt mooi uit. Weinig schuim, dubieuze kleur, maar wat volgt na de eerste slok: Zot bier. Nog nooit zon stijlvolle oude bruine gedronken. Zeer gebalanceerd. Hout zit er duidelijk in, maar in tegenstelling tot mijn hekel hieraan subtiel en zeer gedoseerd aanwezig. Voor de rest zit er zowat alles in... cognac, bruine suiker, heerlijke zuren.

Murky dark brown color with just a bit of tan foam. Aroma has really nice dried fruit notes with lots of sour raisins and some figs. Taste starts sour and fruity with sour cherries and grapes, like a classic flanders ale, but gets more complex with really nice dried fruits, mostly raisins and figs. Its like a sour/acetic quadrupel or something like that. Medium body, slightly syrupy, just a bit of carbonation. A really complex beer with quadrupel type flavors but sour like a flemish ale.
Bottle shared. Dark brown pour with no head. Notes of macerated grapes and cherries, cognac, cocoa, subtle apple and grape vinegar. Medium body, low carbonation and a sour, sweet and bitter finish.

Many thanks for this beer to JefVerstraete. Vintage 2008. Kwasne o owocowej strukturze piwo, a raczej wino smakowalo jak wino malaga, rodzynki i moczona suszona sliwka w spirytusie, wyczuwalny alkohol, ocet winny, ocet balsamiczny, figi i daktyle. jagody i jezyny. Nuty drzewne mocno obecne, wszystko to obtacza mocny kwasek. Fajne i octowo winne piwo. Wyglad to jak po nalaniu do kieliszka dobrego burgundzkiego wina, totalnie zero piany, bardzo ciemno czermone o granatowych przeblyskach, pod swiatlo krwisto atramentowa barwa. Blizej do wina niz do piwa. Super pasuje do wolowiny i dziczyzny. Super

33cl-fles op tasting bij Elie. Merci! U: Donkerbruin met bruine schuimkring. G: Cacao, rood fruit, hout, porto en kruiden. S: Rood fruit, vineus, porto en chocolade. Zoetig met een licht bittertje. Zure afdronk. M: Zeer vicieus met weinig carbonatie.

2008 bottle thanx too John :) First of all i must say that i am not a "fan" of the style...but this beer blew my mind! Sweet and sour with a woody backbone...dark fruit, cherries, dades, figs, plums, nuts and a nice touch of chocolate and even coffee. Really well balanced...sweet nor sour takes the upperhand. The low carbo really works well here. Just lovely!

Appearance: 2008 vintage. Dark brown/red. Basically no head. Pretty flat-looking.
Aroma: Dark fruit, cherries.
Taste: Dark fruit, prunes, cherries, wood. Tartness, but also sweetness. Almost like a port. Better than I expected.
Bought: Trade with tderoeck - thanks!, 330 ml
Info: 22/7-2016, 67/100, BB: 27/4-2016

UPDATED: MAR 24, 2016 2008 bottle at home. Very dark reddish brown colour, no real head just some beige bubbles. Amazingly complex nose with rich porto (!) and red and dried fruity tones, nutty, toffee, cask/vanilla. Beautiful porto, vinous, cask, toffee, herbal tones, medium sour, mildly tard, earthy bitter. Great balance, rounded but big flavours. Intensely lingering red fruity, porto, mildly tard aftertaste. Huge body, low-absent carbonation. Best ale in my favorite style: chapeau.

Bottle shared at Daniels place. 20/02/2016. Many thanks to Paulo for this one. Reddy mahogany brown coloured pour with light tan head. Aroma is red wine vinegar, brown bread, tangy apple. Palate is semi sweet, highish carbonation . Tangy. Flavour is semi sweet, brown bready, granny Smith apple, some spicy vinegar. Some a jammy fruits. Decent.

Bottle share in Richmond, many thanks to Paul for this one. As Struise Aardmonnik / Earthmonk, 2008 vintage, 8%. Very dark brown with a red hue, big foamy brown head. Aroma is malt vinegar, earthy, some sharp acetic stuff, rounded balsamic, rubber. Body is smooth with light carbonation. Taste is vinegar and brown sauce, meaty, a little woody, light acidity with some booze showing up. Pretty nice one to mull over.

2008 bottle in The Beer Temple, generously shared by Trevor, thanks! Dark brown color. No head. Aromas: sour, vinegar, lightly oxidized, raisins. Additionally some sweetness retronasal. Flavor is moderate to full sweet and moderate sour. Light bodied, perhaps because of the lack of carbonation. Flavors linger. Actually really nice, true Flemish.

750ml bottle from trade with fonefan. Thank you Jan! Brown muddy hazy color with small beige head that quickly disappears. Vinous aroma, wood, yeasty, dark tart fruity, light malty, caramel notes when it gets a little warmer. Sweet and acidic taste like aroma. Medium oily body with soft to flat carbonation.

Bouteille datée e 2008. Robe rouge très foncée, pratiquement opaque et sans col de mousse. Jumelée à une très faible effervescence, lapparence est terne. Arômes de vin rouge, cerise, fraise, café, bref, cest maderisé. Légère acidité, balsamique, anis, chocolat et bois mouillé également. On voit que le temps la rattrapé. En bouche, beaucoup plus de saveurs venant de la rouge des Flandre, vin rouge, balsamique, citron, bois sur un fond de grains de café. Beaucoup de baies aussi: fraise, cerise noire et mûre. Pointes danis et zeste de citron. Très faible carbonatation. Texture légère. Spéciale et agréable au goût. Peut-être un peu trop vieille par contre.

Bottle from JefVerstraete, thanks! Surprisingly malty nose, like pumpernikel with bread, vanilla and brown sugar. Also alcoholic. In contrast, due to the slightly vinegar-like acidity, the body does not come across as solid. The carbonation is almost none, while the coffee-infused finish is also alcoholic. This is a very strange flanders red, not really fruity while still decidedly vinous, in part reminiscent of home made wine with added sugar (hence the easily discernable boozy notes). Not sure what to think of this but I would lie if I wrote that I found it tasty.
Bottle at kulminator. Pours deep brown, nose is funky, toffee, balsamic, taste is chewy toffee, sweet, light funk, a bit past its best.

Bottle at Kulminator, finally caught it. Brown pour, small head. Aroma of red grape, oak and milk sour. Taste is long, weird and hard to pinpoint. With wine, vanilla, subtle wild sour oak. Theres a lot going on with this beer, strange and tasty.
Licorice and bourbon smell. Tastes like a heavy red wine. Low carbonation and medium body.

Many thanks to Rian for sharing this 2007 Vintage. Intense sourish woody nose. The beer starts nice earthy and sour. Hints of malty sweetness on a great sourish but still smooth body. Fresh, easy to drink though with a nice depth. Sourish-fresh, earth, dark cherries, no bitterness. Great long sourish earthy dark aftertaste. Great!

Drunk from a Reidal Vinum glass.

in the bottle there is a relatively intense brown sugary quality with just a whiff of the ol sour. Headless in the glass though there are swirling flat one dimensional lacing dots on the surface which creates delicate swirling patterns. Dark chestnut brown with some red rusty highlights. Considering it has no head it looks pretty inviting.
There is a slight vinuous quality and more intense brown sugary sweetness along with cherries surrounded by a golden hue. Some overly ripe apple in there too.
No carbonation but smooth sleek and caressing in the mouth with some fine wafer like instensity on the way down. Much elegance for an 8% ABV beer. Beautifully molded together to form a seemless whole.
the nose from the final drops just goes on and on and on and on and on.
Glorious.

Vintage bottle from spacecoyote for free beer week many thanks! Pours flat reddish brown. Huge wonderful nose of toffee, dark fruit and vinegar. Tastes of cherry, plums, vinegar, red wine, toffee, tobacco, and citrus. Quite tart and semi syrupy. Lovely lingering sourness. Delicious.

Bottle vintage 2008. Muddy brown appearance with a tiny amout of head that vanishes super quick. Aroma is sour cherries, leather, oak, and red grapes. Taste is sour cherries, vinager, oak, and red wine. Finshes tart and acidic, with some malty sweeteness, minimal carbonation. Probably past it a bit, but for this being as old as it is its not half bad.

bottle shared by mathieuc, thanks bro. pours murky and dirty brown with a very small and dissapearing beige cap, no lacing. woody balsamic reduction, vinous character - lots of grapes and red fruitiness - spicy cranberries perhaps, controlled level of sweetness - burnt sugars and roasted candi, some beef stock, light to medium acidity - relatively complex with an acetic touch. low carbonation, medium body - oily; tart, sweetish and woodsy-spicy finish. enjoyed more than i thought i would considering the looks plus first whiff.

Bottle provided by Luk_, thanks a lot for the opportunity! Pours a dark red (a bit murky) with no head except for some large bubbles and no lacing. Nose is of vinegar, oxidation, cheese and light acetone. Taste is of sour red fruits, a bit of garbage, vinegar, nail polish and ends on surprisingly some light sweet notes. Body is medium, carbonation low to medium and mouthfeel a bit coating and oily. Overall not the complete disaster I was expecting but I can say with confidence that it was almost dead by now so drink yours quick. OK, better than Haandbakk.
UPDATED: DEC 15, 2014 At Kulminator. Pours black with very little head. Nose is sour, oak, brett. Taste is like whisky, oaky, oud bruin. Awesome.
Poured a dark reddish brown with a small beige head. Aroma of vinous fruit and caramel malt. Medium body, flavour of the aroma and sour end.

Bottle (2008) at a share courtesy of Eric. Pours a very dark brown without much head. Dark fruits, cherries, some oak, and vanilla and caramel on the nose; follows onto the palate. Finishes with just a little sweetness.

September 28, 2014. Bottle from tderoeck (thanks Tim!), best before august 27, 2018. Pours dark brown almost black with no head. Aroma is cherries, vinegar, oak, caramel light vinous. Taste is tart and sweet with caramel, cherries, dry woody notes. Finish is light to medium dry and medium sweet. Medium bodied, very light/soft carbonation.

2008 Vintage. Pours a deep mahogany umber color with three fingers of eggshell foam that settles to a fingers and lingers nicely. Nose is deep sharp and complex. Vinous acidity, cranberry, blueberry, cocoa, pine, caramel leather, mushroom. Layers nicely and begs to be sipped. Wow, the palate brings me from burgundy to austria and back to napa. Vinous Bomb ! Bright cherry acidity with nuances of herbal blueberry on the front... leading into a juicy cranberry boysenberry midpalate the rounds and softens with rich cocoa dusted blackberry and lingers with wet wood musty basement funk, composted leaves. Next level beer right here.
Bottle @ home. Dark burgundy pour with tiny lacings on top. Very winesque, lots of red grapes, vanilla, raspberries and some light funk. almost flat on the carbonation and finishes dry.
Bottle @Kulminator. Pours dark brown/black with off-white head. Aroma is a bit sour, cherry. Taste little sour, cherry, hint of caramel. Full mouthfeel. Nice one.

11.2oz bottle, thanks to dudeabide for sharing. Bottle is labeled 2008. Kind of hazy dark brown red color. Minimal head. Dark fruit, some oxidization in the nose. Medium plus body. Smooth, kind of creamy, light crisp light carbonation. More dry finish. Some oxidization flavors, moderate sweet, moderate bitter, light tartness, very light spice. Some light bit of alcohol in the finish. Alright, kind of oxidized kind of malty kind of sweet sweeter sour brown ale. Not impressed with this. Too old, I guess.
Niet echt mijn favoriet, maar voor de mensen die graag wijn drinken zal dit een lekker bier zijn

Shared 2006 bottle at home. Poured a deep red brown colour with no head. Cherries, caramel, vinegar, oak, acid, red wine, dark fruits, caramel, some malt sweetness. Incredible beer! Also blended a part to earthnon with reserva 2009. Wich was incredible tasty!!

Two 33cl bottles shared by ygtbsm94. Thanks Brad!

vintage <2010. Review from notes.

The beer is dark mahogany and pretty clear with a broke tan head. Aromas of oak, cherry, funk, vanilla, prune. The flavor is sweet and sour cherry, vinegar, oak, dark fruit finishing with a lactic punch. Acetic and sharp, yet not harsh, per se. Certainly puckering. Complex and intriguing. A unique beer for sure. Id happily try this again.

11.2 oz bottle. Pours a translucent dark reddish brown with a quickly fading head leaving no lacing. Aroma is sweet berries, brettanomyces, and wood. Flavor is overall sweet yet complex: Berries, wood, Brett, dark fruits with cherries and prunes, and grapefruit citrus. Finish is acidic and puckering.

From notes 1/23/10 (Geist Dark Lord Tasting).

Magnifica sour ale colore tonaca di frate scura con pochissima schiuma evanescente. Al naso note di soia, caramello e vino cotto. In bocca una piacebolissima agresività acida e dolce. Corpo denso ma beverino x via dellacidità. La gradazione alcolica li da un tocco di calore liquoroso molto interessante. Il sapore è caramelloso, vinaceo e di frutta secca (uvetta e prugna). Finare lungo molto aromatico.

bottle. 2008. deep red, near brown, with almost head and low pressure when opening cap. aroma of caramel, chocolate, red berries, raisin, old prune. light sourness. dry palate and slight body. juicy texture with low carbonation. low sourness. flavor is a blend of caramel, tart berries, some dust, maybe a touch of molasses.

UPDATED: MAR 3, 2017 An innovative twist on the oud bruin genre, which normally is not spiced, but this one apparently is. Yellow tanned, thin and quickly dissipating head, colour deeply mahogany brown; complex and powerful aroma of raisins, oak, milk chocolate, passion fruit, coffee grounds, candied dates, medium dry sherry, hazelnuts, sour cream, wine vinegar; taste is deliciously complex, exotic fruits, spicy accents, supple and deep malt basis, the sweetishness of which is balanced against the lactic acidity very cleverly. This is truly an addition to the age-old genre of oud bruin and one of the most interesting beers Ive had from this exciting brewery.  Note that this rating concerns the original version, not the re-release of it in 2016, about which I heard mixed opinions...
It is a taste that is similar to red wine is also a refreshing acidity of this cherry beer, and also has been brewed using a wine yeast. It would be nice to drink full day of summer.
(backlog) Bottle (2008). Black pour with some light bubbles. Acetic sour aroma with some acetone/nail polish tones. Sour acetic flavors with lighter cherry and balsamic tones. Very acetic.
At big Seths going away party on 11/2/2013; was an awesome day! Aroma is dark fig, medium acidity. Taste is dark cherries, slightly tart, oak barrel, very very nice.

2008 vintage bottle. Pours a murky, yet vibrant maroon, with a slight plum hue. Maybe even some brown flashes in there too...very interesting appearance with a very thin off-white/pink-tinged cap on top. Aromas of nail polish, red wine vinegar, tart cherries and a slight musty odor. Taste is quite the adventure! Initial tart cherries up front, but this full-bodied beauty gives off some rich flavors of fig, plum, oak, vinous notes/port notes. Some slight spice comes in at the end as well. Such an interesting and delicious beer!! One of the most unique and interesting to this style. Wish I had more!!
Bottle pour sampled during RBWG 2014. Pours opaque black. Nose some sour, slight barrel, dark fruit. Taste tart sour, almost salty, then umami. Sour finish.

Bottle, 2008 vintage, thanks to Alen!! Pours deep mahogany ruby with very little head; an initial bubbly head gives way to a tiny mist of beige lacing along with a ring. Decent lacing nevertheless. Aroma is pretty light overall, presenting an interesting mix of quad characteristics; chocolate, fig, prune, some vinous qualities, a bit of tart cherry. Flavor follows, with some initial sweetness and hints of dark sugars and fig, drying out and becoming lightly tart cherry, oak, vanilla, tannins, ruby port. Dry finish with very light funk, basement flavors coming through at the end. Kind of wine like in mouthfeel, no real carbonation, but still rich and full bodied. Quite the interesting beer, actually.

From notes. Big thanks for OldMrCrow for sharing this with me a few weeks back. I should have entered these notes earlier so I could fill in the gaps better, but Ill do my best. Pours dark ruby with some large bubbles dotting the surface. Aroma: steak sauce, prunes, soy, oak and earth. Perhaps a hint of cheese. Brown sugar. Complex, a shade sweet on the nose - reminds me a bit of cuvée de tomme perhaps? Taste: smoky! Theres the steak sauce. Smoky, sweet, brown sugar, honey, soy prune, a bit tart (but not over the top). Palate: Medium-full body, slick texture, soft carbonation. Oily. Overall: I like this! A little chocolate / roast in there too. Leather, meat, balsamic. After it was mentioned, it smells of dark rubber -- it really does, like a tire. Cool beer -- thanks again for sharing this, OldMrCrow!

Bottle. Pours a dark brown with a medium frothy tan head that diminishes quickly to nothing. The aroma is raisin, caramel, and vinegar. Thin mouth feel with a strong funk, caramel, and light dryness in the finish. Vey good.

Shared bottle at Kulminator. 2008 vintage. Black body with a white film. Port, raisin, prune, vanilla and vinuous notes fill the nostrils. Silky smooth and full bodied prune juice with chutney and notes of liquorice. My mouth really waters up from this potion, I cant help it. Oh bliss!

Bottle at the Kulminator, Antwerp. Poured a murky dark brown with a reddish hue and a round off-white head. The aroma is sour acid, almost vinegar. The flavour is medium sour with a super smooth acid rich fruit alcoholic palate. Medium bodied with flat carbonation. Its surely an acquired taste for some but as soon as you acquire it theres no going back.

Bottle shared with harrisoni in the Molenhof. Thanks Ian. Almost clear but very dark brown, almost no head. Nose is very sour and complex. Balsamic and brown malt vinegar dominates, then its softer vinous red wine grape, cherries, malty grain, tart and sour. Taste is again balsamic vinegar, red wine, vinous grape, tart and sour, touch of caramel. Its a very busy and complex beer where elements are certainly starting to come together although the vinegar maybe hasnt mellowed quite enough to match the softer wine tones.

75cl bottle, shared. 07/11. Almost black, thin head. Vinegar aroma, balsamic. Covers all else. Flavor has tartness, vinegar, salty cucumber. 1 dl was quite enough. Not bad, but really balsamic vinegary stuff, which is borderline for me.-- rated with beerbasher/winphone

750ml bottle @ Pikkulintu, Helsinki
BBE 07/11 - Pours dark brown, almost black with a tiny head. Aroma of vinegar, sour berries, tartness, cherries and off flavors. Taste is smooth, sweet and sourish with notes of vinegar, balsamico, berries, tartness and cherries. Finish is smooth, sourish and sweet with notes of vinegar and earthy notes. Quite messy and strange. Probably has seen its best days a few years ago.

33cl bottle, shared with Mathieu87.
APPEARANCE: dark red beer, little to no foam.
NOSE: sour, wood, cherries, little earthy even.
TASTE: sourness, but moderate, some fruits, cherries, wood.
This was an older vintage, in my memory the others I had where better!

2008, thanks Seth! Translucent red-brown with some minimal bubbles. Red wine / vinous aroma, hints of leather. 

Taste impresses: cherries & red grapes, vinegary, dark fruit at the end. Finishes dry and champagne-like (minus the carb). Really damn good.

Bottle shared at Darkness Day by StFun, thanks Josh! Pours a hazy brown, sour hits the nose and makes my mouth water slightly. Taste is sweet then sour like a sour patch kid. Some woody undertones. Solid.

Bottle shared at Darkness Day by StFun, one of the only users to be banned on Ratebeer! Thanks!! Dark hazy brown in color, a little sour - acetic and a touch lactic. Nice balance with sweetness of the malt.
UPDATED: JUN 14, 2014 330ml bottle. So sour, flat, caramel, berries and wood aromas and flavours. Maybe a bit unbalanced, sourness dominated, other flavours fading.

The beer pours flat with a very dark cola color to it that passes no light through it at all, has no head and leaves no lacing on the glass. The beer scent is average as it has a mild smell of dark fruit with a follow up of a bitter pinot noir flavor. The taste is great with a definite blend of dark bitter cherry and black currants and a mild pinot noir finish, similar to the smell but this actually blend together well. The mouthfeel is mediocre as the beer had almost no carbonation but has a bitter, dry mouthfeel. Overall, this flemish sour had some highs and low...the lows were poor carbonation and mild smell...the highs were a solidly blended sour ale. It was nice to try but Ill pass going forward.

Bottle from a shop in Belgium (think it was the Struise shop in Brugge), bought in 2011 (2008 on the bottle). This beer had lots of aceton-like notes in it a couple of years ago but trying it now i 2013 most of it is gone. I can still sense some though. Fruity and sour with some chemical notes. Not very refreshing.

UPDATED: FEB 14, 2015 Pours with no head. Before I even have time to observe the colors, a sharp acetic note has already wafted to my nose. Color of rich black earth mud, but not cloudy at all. Looks like very strong iced black tea. Aroma is of spiced bread (heavier on the spice than the bread): clove and nutmeg, sweet tea, vinegar, tart grape and cherry. No carbonation on palate. Flavor is quite tart, high in acetic acid to the point of excess. Caramel malt. Acetic is zesty, dominant. Just when I though tit was going to be a detriment, the spices kick in and round out these sharp notes: nutmeg, cinnamon, light licorice and clove, hint of black pepper. Grape juice (made from wine grapes). Light, dry, old, nutty woodiness. As it warms and breaths, I adapted to the acetic zest and thought a bit more highly of the beer. Some elements are great: spice, fruit, and intensity of flavor, while the lack of carbonation makes the beer less enjoyable. Not worth the very high price.
Bottle at Kulminator, Antwerrp. 2005 vintage. Dark brown beer with a beige head- Fruity, cherries aroma almost a bit like red wine. Red berries, sweet, a bit earty, a bit mushroom notes (?), flavour.
Bottle @ Kulminator, RBESG. Very dark brown colour with a tan head. Nose is slightly sour, fruits, bit of yeast. Flavour is sour, acid, balsamic vinegar, dark fruits. Finish is fairy sour.
Bottle, thank you GT2! Aroma of oak, red wine, cherries. Hazy, very dark color, almost no head nor lace. Overall amazing sour though!

Poured super dark brown with a loose deep tan head. Smell is tobacco, cherry, balsamic and wood. The taste follows the nose with some chocolate and molasses thrown in...very tannic. Medium body and mildly carbonated. Great stuff.

virtually no head, beige colour. dark ruby-red colour. complex aroma, wood, oak, acetobacter, balsamico, red fruits. delicious sour taste with balsamic and wood. in one word: divine!! 2006 edition / 75 cl @ kulminator / notes from backlog

Enjoyed at Kulminator. Bottle was November of 2005

A -  Dark brown. Great lacing. 

S - Smells flat and full of cherries and mango and corn syrup

T -  Taste is whoa. Great balance. Insanely drinkable. Love the cherries. Love the mild carbonation. Love the oak and sweetness. 

M - Medium carbonation, smooth light body with a sharp acidic finish

O - This is remarkable. Eff you rodenbach. I could drink this daily. But no older than this. Its starting to see signs of oxidation

Bottle via trade, 2008. Dark reddish brown with a minimal spotty head. Aroma of balsamic vinegar, cherries, oak and band aide.  Flavor is tart sour cherry, dry oak and lightly sweet caramel/toffee. Medium to light body with a thin mouth feel. Not a big fan of this one, thin, flabby body with an odd sourness.

330mL bottle, sent from Glouglouburp (thanks a lot, Dany), pours a completely still dark mahogany, just a few bubbles. Nose is super vinous, full of red wine barrels, oak, loads of wood, a touch of vinegar, and sour dark fruits. Flavour is very similar with loads of depth and complexity, with notes of oak, wood, red wine barrels, some port liqueur without the sweetness, and moderately sour dark fruits. Very deep and massively vinous and oak. Excellent stuff, quite atypical from a standard sour.

(Cuvée 2008): Rouge profond avec une tête étonnement crémeuse mais qui se dissipe rapidement. Larôme est invitante, rhubarbe, chlorophylle, terre humide, grange, vanille. La présence en bouche est assez unique, une rondeur exceptionnelle transporte des notes surettes jamais trop insistante. La base maltée est robuste, une sour brown définitivement impériale, une gorgée à la fois.

Bottle at home, 2008 vintage EM No.7, thanks to Essex Jim for the trade.
Pours a murky dark brown with reddish hues, very thin off white head that clears to the edge and vanishes completely after a few minutes.
Nose is sour as fuck, balsamic vinegar, damp wood, tarte raspberries, red wine, polly filler.
Tastes of soured raspberries, sweet balsamic vinegar - berry flavoured, sour tarte berry fruits, some sugars.
Full end of medium bodied with a touch of fine carbonation, dry and tarte in the finish.
Good puckering stuff!
user_location: Hazlemere, the lower Xhitlerns, Buckinghamshire, ENGLAND

text: 2011 vintage Thanks James! Poured into a tulip head made up of big bubbles.  Nose is like a strong malbec or cab, fruity and welcoming.  I get hints of bourbon.  Mouthfeel is rather is thin. Taste is really complex, damp cellar and raspberries. Finish has a strong tart sting, evokes 9V battery to the tongue.
Deep cherry red pour. Cherry, balsamic vinegar, and tartness. Sweet cough syrup, brown sugar, and sour/sweet. Medium body and seems to me more the the 8% to me.

2007 vintage. At the kulminator shared with kermis.
Decent creamy off white head.
Deep burgundy pour.  Sour aroma.  Sour taste but a Goodyear

(Bottle, Chez Moeder Lambic St Gilles, Brussels, 19 Oct 2012. Vintage 2008) Dark brown colour with foamy, beige head. Fruity, sour nose with notes of caramel, balsamic vinegar, dried fruit and brown sugar. Fruity, tart/sour taste with balsamic vinegar, dark fruit, over-ripe pears and a solid vinegar sourness in the finish. Not quite as balanced as the Rodenbach Grand Cru, but still an impressive sour ale. Something of an acquired taste, but I really like it. Lovely!
bottle poured into a tulip glass  the pour looked like red wine, flat with no head at all.   smeel was sweet and malty.  taste was sweet n sour, slightly too sweet for my liking.
Dark brown and thin beige lace. Licorice, earthy, balsamic, sour. Taste is sharp sour, red wine vinegar, old. Crazy but not nice (any more?). Unique but way too sharp. Thin body. No thanks. (UDRBM)

UPDATED: JAN 17, 2015 Bottle 330ml [2008]
Pours brown with reddish reflects. Flat. Aroma is of fruits, sligth vinegar, malt, metal, caramel. Taste is of fruits, caramel, acidity, sligth metal. Palate: No carbonation, some oxidation, slightly sitcky texture. Overall: Too old I would guess. Not impressive. (5/2/5/2/11). [Edit: Revisited this one: 330ml. Bottle. Unknown vintage, will update with info. Pours very dark brown/purple with no serious head nor lacing. Aroma is of intense fruits, nail polish remover, lots of green apples, madeira. Taste is of acid, sugar, roasted malt, madeira, fruits. Palate: Full bodied. Very soft to no carbonation. Overall: Good, fruity. Quite acetic. Balance not too shabby. This bottle was in a way better condition than the other one I had. Still, I dont consider this beer a masterpiece. Glad I could revisit. (7/2/7/2/14)

Bottle (330 ml) 2008. Reddish brown with no head and no lacing. Aroma of red fruits, vinegar, ketchup, wood and oxidation notes. Not sure I want to go further... Taste is of red fruits (mostly cherries), caramel, chocolate, vinegar, tart fruits. Mouthfeel is thin and completely flat. This beer is quite complex, but I dont think that all those flavors get along very well.

3.0 A: Pours a completely still brownish black color.

2.5 T: The taste is just as forceful as the nose. This starts out with a marriage between the balsalmic vinegar and the acetone. Cherries follow next. Tobacco and soy sauce after that. Molasses, vinous grape, and a bit of oak. 

2.0 M: Medium body. Almost no carbonation. Almost slick. Cant say this is very smooth.

2.5 D: This is wholely unrefined. Im okay with the sourness and the balsalmic flavors. Hell, sometimes Ill pour a quarter ounce of balsalmic vinegar into a snifter just to sip on. Super complex and powerful, but just not that good.

The taste is something quite wonderful though.  This is probably the finest tasting oude bruin ive had, with oude tart being my previous favorite.

I love this beer, its a shame I only bought 6. Will have to buy some more when more is released.

Bouteille de 33cl. Vintage 2010. Merci Julien. Versée tel que mentionné dans une tulipe. Cette bière est brune avec des reflets rouges. La mousse est brune et forme une légère couche. Le nez est vineux, on penserait à des cerises fermentées dans des fûts de noisette enrobée de chocolat.  La bouche est agréable, des notes de vieux vins sont présents. La texture est grasse car il ny a peu de gaz carbonique. Le suret est bien balancé et il nest pas agressant. Produit distinctif.

Bottle from a minitrade with Countbeer. Got this in person At De Molen festival. Thank you pal. Lets do it again next year. The pour ia dark dark  muddy brown with a no head at all. The nose is nice and sour with fine wooden notes that gives it almost a vinoes impression. There is some dark sugar and cinnamon. My first impression of the taste is a bit salty follow by a deep wooden sourness. Its totaly flat witch makes it a little strange and leaves a thick watery palate. The finish has a nice blend of sweet notes and a sour agressivness with a bitterness in the end. A little disappointed, but still a ok taste that would have been much more interesting if it had been spiked up by some carbonation.

33cl traded bottle. There is a lot going on here and I appreciate it. Biggest thingis dont drink it too cool because the sourness comes off as harsh. Lots of puckering sourness and mouth-drying tannins. Really unique.

(11.2 oz bottle).  Pours a dark brown with tan head.  Aroma has lots of fruits (sour concorde grapes?), and vinegar.  Taste is sweet and sour and maybe a tad bit oxydized.  Medium bodied with a slick texture.  Dry finish.  Really nice beer.

Nice sour. Beautiful golden color with a cloudy pour.
Flavor is a little dry.

Bottle [330ml] shared with HogTownHarry & garthicus -- c/o HogTownHarry.  2008 vintage. Pours dark brown, almost black, with a spare diminishing bubbly off-white head. Aroma of apple vinegar along with red wine, sour fruit and caramel malt. Flavours quite sour and somewhat vinegary with with red wine, sour fruit and caramel malt. Average bodied. Its a bit of an odd duck but its pretty good.

(Courtoisie de JulienHuxley, 33cl, vintage 2008)  Le liquide a une robe brune.  Aucune construction mousseuse.  Au nez, les malts légèrement chocolatés, les épices et les herbes à la «chinotto» se choquent à des raisins oxydés et à des parfums boisés.  Au goût, les épices sont expressives.  Les fruits portent une aigreur rapidement rattrapée par les sucres.  Des caractéristiques vineuses sont présentes : on croirait boire par moment quelque chose qui ressemble à un vermouth.  Aussi, quelques traces de vinaigre balsamique qui sont, bien sûr, diluées.  En bouche, le liquide a un corps passablement rond avec un pétillement très doux et une texture qui est, à la limite, huileuse.  La finale est remplie de notes douces et de notes aigres, passablement longues, fruitées et épicées.  Wow!  Toute une surprise.
Bottle, pours a very dark hazy, dark fruits, the beer tastes very sour with a thick body, it is quite interesting but not my favourite

Details: 33cl bottle, vintage 2008.
Tasting notes: Poured vigorously to get a big bubbled head on top of the dark colored beer. The head evolves into a ring of bubbles with some clouds in the middle. The nose is complex, notes of vinegar, fresh sour apples, lots of oak. The flavor starts very smooth and when you swallow it you get a powerfull but gentle acetic burn which reminds me of the Earthmonk Ive tasted directly from the cask and I liked very much. Afterwards you get a complex aftertaste with notes of sour apples, oak, vinous touches, .. . Too complex to be accurately described, so Ill definitely enjoy degustating this beer some more times. The carbonisation is very flat but this just adds a special feeling to this beer.
Conclusion: a complex, tasteful and truly authentic Flemish sour ale.

2008 bottle. 33cl. Pours ruby black with no head. Aroma of strong vinegar, tart berry and grape...just killed in red wine vinegarette. Flavor is wildly flemish, tart and full of grapes...more subdued in the vinegarette aspect, and full of concord, blackberry, and currants. Extremely unique, and very enjoyable

Time to go against the grain here. A dark amber color with no head. The aroma smells like an attic full of boxes of rotting cherries. The flavor is sweet and cloying like going on a bender with those chocolate covered cherries you see around Christmans . Vegetable oil coating on the tongue. This is too much right here.
Bottle from the Struise bottle shop in Brugge. Poured dark brown with little head. Aroma is mostly of dark malts with some sour notes. Taste is similar. I would like to try again.

Bottle. Dark brown, no head. Moderate, sourish and sweetish aroma, dark sweet fruitiness, some vanilla/oak and faint alcohol. Body is medium, sourish and sweetish flavor, vinous - dark sweet fruits, some vanilla.Finish is average, sourish and sweetish, dark fruitiness with some vanilla. Nice one  really good balance between sourness and sweetness.
I am not a huge fan of balsamic vinegar, and yet I dug the balsamic vinegar character that permeated this beer. Licorace, spruce, tobacco, some molasses, too,. Well made and tasty.

Very dark brwon with almost no head, few large beige bubbles. Aroma is soil, fortified wine, sourness and a bit of dried fruit. Taste is initially sweet like a strong well steeped very sugary tea mixed with a bit of sherry booziness. Then sour finish. Very full bodied. Cracking and very interesting beer!

UPDATED: SEP 29, 2011 2007 vintage at Kulminator. Pours a dark brown colour with a fair light tan head. An unbelievable nose, quite sour with balsamic vinegar, a little iron, chocolate and coffee. Similar flavours with a metallic blood like character and a roasted barley backbone. Little dry finish. Oily mouth-feel, mild carbonation and CO2 prickle. This is so tasty with a long linger.

2010 bottle from Cracked Kettle. Lot 10/08/24/03/2011. Best before 27/04/2016. I much prefer the first batch I had, best before 07/2010. Pours a dark brown colour with an orange - red tinge. No head. Fairly typical Flemish red nose with some metallic and earthy qualities and a little pickled onion / balsamic vinegar. Tastes quite sour with a metallic blood like character. Fairly fruity with raisins and plums. This has improved since I had another bottle from this batch in May. I am getting a bit of diacetyl still so Ill let the last one sit. Still good though. (6,2,8,4,16).

UPDATED: MAY 21, 2013 A fantastic new version of the classic Flemish sour ale. It is a blend of old and young Pannepot giving it a very distinct taste. It is a dark brown beer with absolutely no head. Its great however to see a classic style be reinvented. A breath of fresh air.

Muy interesante salvajada.
Notas a especies,compleja,parece un buen vino.
Muy interesante
Bebida en el Drunk Monk

Bottle shared by MrPickles - Murky brown pour with no head at all. Aroma brings a whiff of metal, red wine, sharp oakiness, a bit of plastic and a touch of sour malt. Dry red wine taste...waay better than the smell--overlaid upon a sweet, lightly soured malt base. Black cherries, smooth all the way through the finish, which ends with some bitter, sharp oakiness. Smooth, with minimal carbonation and a slick body. Pretty nice, but brought down by the aroma.
330cl bottle at home kindly shared by oj83. This was wrong! Tasted like Rodenbach with an infection.... Was a drainpour
Bottle.  Reddish brown pour with a minuscule head.  Sour fruit and vinegar aromas.  The taste follows suit with semi tart stone fruits, vinegar, caramel malt, vanilla, and subtle oak flavors.
Had this one at the ACBF 2011. Dark brown, red colored brew. Sour fruits, berries, some dark malts, vinegar, wood. Very balanced, nice beer.

UPDATED: OCT 6, 2013 33cl bottle of the 2008 batch from the Struise store in Bruges. Cloud dark brown with a reddish tinge. No head even with an aggressive pour. Aroma is red wine, balsamic vinegar, figs, blackcurrant. Taste is like sour candies, tart berries, or raspberry vinegarette, heavy on the sourness with a complimentary level of sweetness and no hint of bitterness. 

2006 Edition
Last bottle in stock at Kulminator, thanks to Dirk for parting with it. Deep brown with a good pale head. Aroma is balsamic reduction, fig, prunes, molasses. Full bodied, thick mouthfeel - almost sticks to the roof of the mouth - fantastic balance of sweet and sour on the palate, long complex finish. Taste is balsamic reduction, fig, molasses, dried dark fruits, hint of liquorice. Fucking fantastic.
A 9, L 4, T 9, P 5, O 19 => 4.6

Most recent vintage courtesy of pittsburghkid66. Served in a Mikasa tulip.

Pours a dark brown color with some reddish-mahogany highlights. A few light tan bubbles to start and then it falls completely flat, which is then echoed in the flavor and feel. The nose brings a bit of light soy sauce and mild sweetness, which, oddly enough, reminds me a bit of 2009 Dark Lord. Slight cherry cherry along with lactic acid and a bit of vinegar. The flavor goes straight from the nose bringing through cherry, soy sauce, vinegar, and some very mild sweetness. Light body with very low carbonation and a pretty heavy acetic acid presence. Definitely not for everyone, but I quite enjoyed this.

Serving type: bottle
Scent of balsamic vinegar. Likewise acidity in its flavour. Much more drinkable than Rodenbach, in my opinion.

Dark red brown med hardly no head (a beige layer on top is all). Red wine, plum, grapes, brown sugar, fruit, berries and christmas spices (cardamom) in aroma. Berries, grapes and a vinous sourness in flavour. This could easily be served instead of red wine. Love it.

33cl sent generously by AleWatcher & shared with friends. Pours flat with little bubbles. Smells of vinegar and sour, dark malt along with belgian candied sugar and paint thinner. Taste is full of plum, blueberry, figs, black cherry and vinegar on the finish. Very different beer and Im not sure that I could drink more than 11.2 oz to myself, but I really enjoyed it.

Bottle, courtesy GT2. Pour is dark ruby with a few sad bubbles comprising the head formation. Smell is straight balsamic vinegar, maybe with some red wine or cough syrup. Taste is an improvement: still very red wine balsamic heavy with some blackberries, oak, medicinal notes. Palate is medium, sharp carbonation with a tart/dry finish. I was told this was a bad bottle so I plan on giving it another shot when I get the chance.

33 cl bottle. 2008 vintage. Dark brown liquid with very small or no head. Smells of vinegar, green apples and medicinal alcohol. A bit smoke/malt. Taste is a bit sour (vinegar) and light sweetness and no bitterness and lots of malt, caramel and so on. Medium bitter and little carbonation. Nice overall, very nice tasting but a bit unrefined taste.

From tap @Mikkeller.  Pours a dark brown to near black body. Virtually no head, only a film of tiny tanned bubbles.  Prominent  sourish fruit aroma. Black currants, plum marmelade and grapes. Notes of balsamico and barnyard. Taste is vinous, sour and vinegary, and substantially fruity. Currants, cider apples and rhubarb. Fine notes of vanilla and wood. Some sweetness from the alcohol. Body is more than medium full. Amazingly smooth in the mouth.  Packed and higly complex, still appears as a well balanced beer. So nice!

Bottle. Huge thanks to a fellow craft head for trading me a glass of this for some belgian red that I was drinking. Pour is a murky brown, with medium lacing and not much head. Aromas of barley wine booze, pinot noir, earthy hops, carmelized sugar, peat, whiskey, smoked wood. Taste is purple grapes, honey mead, peat, sour cherries, brandy, and a slew of other complex tasting spices and wood notes. Amazingly unique for a wild ale with a soft as silk mouthfeel. Wow, what a beer.

Bottle shared by Kyle, thanks! Poured a clear rosy amber with a small white head that dissipated to the edges. Aroma reminded me a lot of balsamic with some vinegar and dark tart fruits with a good amount of acid. Flavor started with a light sour dark fruit note with a bit of vinegar and a good amount of acid. A bit different but good.

Bottle poured as per the Struise recommendations gives purplish brown murky liquid with moderate brief head of large bubbles.  Aroma sour and fruity.  Taste of plums, wine, slight wood and vinegar.  Tart sour grape finish.  Palate full and rich.  Alcohol slightly apparent.
I am not a big sours guy and didnt  expect to like this much, but I did.  I thought the flavor was actually fairly simple but very good.

Pour from a bottle into a Belgian chalice. Murky amber brown in color with almost no head at all.Aromas of vinegar and chocolate malt. Full body on your tongue and palate. Flavors in this beer are rich and exceptional; tart cherry, plum, and toasty oak. Long lingering complex finish. Fantastic.

Bottle. A typical Struise beer! It has got the "Struise-smoothness" and the "Struise-agening quality". Its not overly sour. The sourness is rather fruity. It has also got notes of raisin, soy, and wood. Earthy. A very complex beer!

Bottle.
Pours dark brown, coffe like without any head.
Aroma of sour medecin, licorice and paint. Complex and interesting, but not very welcomeing...

Smooth and heavy mouthfeel. Complex taste like the Pannepots, fruity of raisins and plums with a yoghurty tartness.
Dark coke color. Very acidy and sour. medium body, Wine-like. Not a favourite.

UPDATED: NOV 5, 2013 Keg at The Wedding. Pours hazy brown with a modest head. Heavy sour notes and strong acidity. Flavor is piercingly sour with an almost vinaigrette character, along with light sweetness and hints of caramel. Medium bodied with fine carbonation. Sour and acidic finish, hints of oak and dark fruits. Very good. (4.0)Draft at ACBF 2011. Pours dark brown with a faint, filmy head. Sour cherry nose, light fruity sugars. Super sour flavor with mild sweetness, some rindy bitterness, other fruits. Medium bodied with lively carbonation. Sharp, clean sour finish, some cherry fruits, faint dry and dark sugars. Very, very good. (4.2)
Sampled @ ACBF 2011, 2008 vintage. Color brown with tiny head. Aroma vinegar, cherries, sour. Taste sour, cherries wine, vinegar.

08 bottle courtesy GT - thanks!  Pours with tiny, scattered bubbles on a rusty brown colored beer that goes flat quickly.  A second into another glass from a bit of height gives me a bigger slick of brown foam but that fades out as well.  Aroma is a funky combination of off-sour, caramelized sugar, musty oak, leather, soft raisin, and a tinge of tart fruit that I cannot quick identify.  Wow - very odd but enjoyable taste and much better than the aroma predicts.  Taste is a chewy, wine-like sour with sweet and tart fruit notes (cherry?).  Some noticeable sweet malt and raisin on the back 3rd of the taste at it warms.  Fairly light and clean in the mouth with the sour/tart notes lingering after each sip.  Quite enjoyable on the whole.

Small bottle shared at Seans 30th Birthday Tasting. Pours a nice dark brownish pour, a good haze, with some ruby edges, a small tannish head dies to near nothing. Aromas are sweeter cherries, touches of red fruit, sweet bready and caramel malts, touches of sweet raisins. Not nearly as sour as anticipated. Decent sourness on the nose. Initial is decent touch of vinegar, red wine, sour cherries, more gentle with a vinegar kick. Sour cherries are more gentle, inviting with some bready malts, toast, lactic acid. Touches of oak, sweeter malts. Into the finish is lingering cherry tannins, wet oak, sweeter malts, toast, sour fruits. Gentle, the sourness doesnt assert itself. Solid, but not world moving. Interesting. A healthy sour kick, but dies out into sweeter malts. A touch minerally and iron-esque on the nose.

Keg at MesandSims crazy wedding party! It pours very dark brown, with a thin foamy tan head and soft carbonation. The nose is sweet balsamic vinegar, tart cherry, malt vinegar, varnish, liquorice, dark chocolate, permanent marker pen and petrol. The taste is balsamic vinegar, cherry, sweet strawberry, tar, charcoal, soy sauce, varnish, petrol, tar, raisin, malt vinegar, molasses and treacle, with a sweet-tart finish. Well balanced, complex, interesting and very drinkable. A classy beer.

33 cl bottle, 2008 vintage. Murky brown pour, no head. Aroma of vinegar, ketchup, brown sugar, raisins and cherries. Very strong aroma, not exactly balanced. Taste is better, slightly vinegary, quite a bit of cherries and brown sugar, nice sweetness and a tart finish. Palate is flat, and despite all the sweetness, the tart finish leaves a rather dry feel. My overall impression is that this beers aroma, even though it eventually grows on to you, is way too overpowering and aggressive for the subtle acidic flavors.

33cl bottle 2008. Brown with no head (did not pour generously though). Malt, molasses, raisins, vinegar. Tangy/sour, acidic and no carbonation on the palate, malty and vinegar on the palate - not quite sure I get this, maybe it needs to sit and bottle condition for a while, or maybe the Flemish sour style just isnt for me. We shall see.

Bottle from EtreGourmet, shared with Palme. 2008 edition. Had to grab this from the EG webshop when it was announced, as people went bananas to get the 2011 version in the Struise webshop a bit earlier. Since Belgian "oud bruin" sour isnt my favorite genre, I figured this one might help on the impression. :-) Pours a deep ruby-hued brown body with virtually no head. Nose is smooth, mellow and yet pungent with complexity: vinegar, alcohol, tomatoes (new one! :-P), herbs, spices, red berries, wood and hints of nail polish and balsamic. Taste is equally complex; balsamic, extremely smooth wooden notes, salty tones of tomato, red berries and tart red apple tones. Hints of nail polish and dark malts in the back. Wow. This is pretty far out; so smooth, weird and complex at the same time. Although Im still not quite sold on the genre, this is by far the best old Flemish ale Ive had so far and I gotta give credit where credit is due. ;-)

Growler by Anker. Thanks a bunch. Pours hazy deep amber with a creamy off white head. The aroma is acid, raisins, caramel, balsamicco and vinegar. The flavour is raisins, balsamicco, caramel, acid and oak.

Thanks to Anker for sharing. Hazy dark brown with an off-white head. Aroma is medium sweet, moderate sour, dried fruit, earth and vinegar. Flavor is medium sweet and rather sour. Dry and acidic finish. 270511

Bottle:
Small layer of big airy tan bubbles, that disappear really quick, on top of a dark brown to an almost black colored beer.
Smell is a balanced smell of liquorice, vinegar, overripe fruit, brown sugars and sweet soya sauce.
Taste is a good balanced mix of sours, liquorice, toasted malts, herbs, light vinegar, darker ripe fruits, yeast and a hint of spices.
Aftertaste is a bit of a lesser nice mix of dark fruits, herbs, liquorice and nasty malts. The lesser part is the malty aftertaste.
Very low to no carbo, soft mouthfeel, full body and a watery texture. Nice brew!
user_location: Best of E-Town mit 2 Brauhausen, NETHERLANDS

text: Sampled from a bottle with a hinged porcelain top. Thanks to Anker for sharing. Opaque, dark-brown body. No head whatsoever. Sour-sweet smell of fruits and caramel malts. Vinous taste containing tart berries, oak and malts. Long-lived finish of sourness and sweetness. A mellow and palate cleansing brew (Copenhagen, 27.05.2011).

Draught at Mikkellerbar 2011-05-27 Copenhagen
AR: barrell aged balsm vinagear, 
AP: dark reddish, nohead
F: sour, tart, sticky

33cl bottle, best by 27042016.  Pours a dark brown color with no real head to speak of.  Aroma is fruity, sour. Medium on the palate with little to no carbonation.  Flavor is sour, spicy, cherry, a little yeasty, with a sour-bitter finish.  Very tasty.  I have a few more bottles of this, so I will need to re-rate once they have had some time to condition.

(33cl bottle best by 8/2011 thanks to Exiled) clear rich ruby with no bubbles. Nose of maple, oak, currants, sour fruit, cherry, and pipe tobacco. Very complex nose. Taste of tobacco, vinegar, quite sweet, and somewhat disappointed in the taste.
UPDATED: AUG 8, 2014 I tasted the 2007 and 2009 version. One of the best beers of the Struise brewers. Perfect balance between sweet, sour and bitter. I wish i had more of these.

Draught at Mikkeller Bar, Copenhagen. Black beer, small beige head. Sourish fruity aroma, salmiak, yeasty notes. Sourish vinous flavor, grapes, citrus, grapefruit, some berries, some soot. Vinous berry finish.
Thanks to Anker for sharing. Brown with small off-white head. Flavour is malt, sour, tart, barnyard, fruit, vinegar and citrus.

Tap @ Mikkeller Bar. Weird brownish grey color, small white collar. Aroma has vinegar, oak, salt, balsamico-vinegar and is extremely well-balanced and positively lovely. Taste reveals sweetness and sourness in almost perfect harmony; tons of sweet and sour berries with oak for a nice and sweet burn. Also a lot of vanilla. I love it.

UPDATED: AUG 8, 2014 Pours matt/greyish dark brown with allmost no head. Aroma of vinegar, sweet oaked balsamic, light salty, bready, sour and light earthy. Taste of sour yeast, oaked balsamic, vinegar, blackberries, light acid, earth, bread and a bit salty. Outstanding characteristic taste and smell. very harmonic.

clear amber, smooth offwhite head.
aroma: complexx, sour, caramel. malts. dark fruits.
flavor is citrussy, driend dark fruits, tartness, sweet caramel balance, very complex,tasty.

A funky, acidic nose, pours dark red, almost black, very little head. Complex taste - very acidic, but the malty sweetness and woody and earthy tones makes it quite balanced, although almost overwhelming in its intensity. A very special beer.

Draught @ Mikkeller Bar, Copenhagen. Rated @ 27.5.2011.
Pours a deep brown colour with a small, beige head. Aroma of lovely ripe, sour fruits, cherries and mild smoke. Flavour of ripe, sour fruits, some smoke, wood, caramel, yeast and lingonberries. Medium bodied with a thick mouthfeel and a sour, fruity finish. Very tasty.

12 oz bottle, recently received in a trade. Shared with buds at Bryans tasting. Poured a deep  brownish body with a minimal head, Aromas of malty wine, fruits and bitter chocolate. Taste is a bit sour and unusual. Has a wine-like character with woody notes and a slightly tart finish. Interesting stuff, but not what i was hoping for.

Growler from Mikkeller bar brought with me and shared at CBF2011. 
Pours a mahogany-brown colour with a white rim. 
Aroma is sweet balsamic vinegar, wood, red fruits and some caramel. 
Flavour is smooth and delicious dominated by oak aged balsamic vinegar, with strong notes of oak, caramel, dark fruits and a hint of apples. Nice and sour vinegar finish.
Sur med en lätt touch av oliver i lukten. Krämig och fylligt sur i smaken med en behagligt surt eftersmak.

A very, very opaque brown color. I cannot see light through it, and it is still a bit turbid. I do get hints of light at the small of the glass and the top edges. There is a faint red tint to it. Flat, still pour. No head, even when forcing it. A very pungent acetobacter (vinegar) aroma. Very strong. There is a big malty aroma under this as well. Much like a big barleywine that may have gone bad from oxygen exposure. In this case it was intentional though. Leaves a caramel tint on the glass after taking a sip and the liquid falls back to its temporary residence. Some points it smells like a quad with barely any sourness, but that may be the vinegar smell saturating my senses until I clear them.

The taste is a very mixed bag of flavors. I get the sweet malt up front. Much like a quad in this regard. Then the sourness hits me. It isnt overpowering like the smell would lead one to believe. It is subtle but in your face. An oxymoron of a presence. There is also a big alcohol presence in both taste and mouth feel. A slight bitterness makes its way into the mouth as well. Its not the sour, its something else. Maybe some hops, as I get a bit of a vegetal taste also. But fairly subdued. A very earthy taste as well. Could be from the barrel, as is most of the oxygen characters Im picking up. Im digging it. Its very complex. Like a sherry, but maltier. Fruity and sour, with sweetness mixed in. There is a burning in the throat after each swallow that is a combination of the vinegar and alcohol notes. Not over the top. 
Awesome beer.

Bottle...  Poured deep, burgundy, dark brown with a bubbly head.  Aroma of acetone and soured fruits.  Light body, mild carbonation that added a hint of fizziness.  Dark sugar tones, acetone and vinegar like yeast tartness.  Crazy tart and sour but not palate stripping puckering in any way.  Notes of oak, light alcohol heat, candied apples and grapes, malt sweetness and a hard candy, jolly roger finish.

The 2011 version. When I visited the Old School, they just put the Earthmonk 2011 for sale. Lucky me! 

Pours a dark-amber brown with some thin layer of bubbles forming a nice lacing.
Smell is very sweet with strong sour notes of balsamic vinegar, brown sugar, oak, some dark fruits but surprisingly, also clear notes of red fruits were present. Everything mingled perfectly together. The best smelling Vlaams oud bruin I had until now. 
Taste: Dark fruits, red fruits, lots of brown sugar and smooth oaky vinegar all over the place. This beer is so smooth, it is hard to describe.
Overall: When I had the beer, it was still very young. So nice and soft, with all flavors coming out very balanced. Probably overtime the sourness will get a bit more pronounced, but for me, this beer is close to perfect now!

330ml bottle BIG thanks to Joris.
Appearance : Dark red with no head.

Aroma : Big notes of cherries and chocolate with light alcohol and vinegar notes. Nice spices.

Taste : Cherries and chocolate. A bit mineral with light fruits. Finish acidic and lactic with great sweet cherries notes. Quite sour. Nice mouthfeel despite the very soft carbonation.

Overall : Wow this was very different. Very complex and packed with flavours. I really liked the cherries/chocolate mix along with the sourness. However, its a bit too lactic for my taste. The finish was also a little bit too mineral. Still this is worldclass and Im really happy I got to try it. Unique and very well crafted.
